title: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio Exits Democratic Presidential Race
text:
New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said Friday he was dropping out of the Democratic presidential race, after failing to gain traction with voters.

“The bar is so high so early,” he said of fundraising and poll requirements for debates, in comments on MSNBC.

“I started later than I would have liked,” he said in explaining why he failed to build support.

SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS Why do you think Bill de Blasio failed to stand out among the group of Democratic candidates? Join the conversation below. Mr. de Blasio, who faced criticism at home for mounting a long-shot campaign, has been mayor of New York City since 2014 after earlier elected posts as the city’s public advocate and on New York City Council. He won re-election in 2017. In his run for president, Mr. de Blasio’s platform centered on working people. While in office, he has pushed progressive policies, including universal pre-K and ending the New York Police Department’s use of a tactic known as stop-and-frisk to address neighborhood crime. During the July candidate debates, Mr. de Blasio pressured former Vice President Joe Biden to say whether he had pushed to stop deportations under President Obama. But Mr. Biden demurred, saying: “I keep my recommendation to him in private.” When asked Friday about Mr. Biden’s candidacy, the mayor said, “I think we need a progressive.” Write to John McCormick at mccormick.john@wsj.com
